close_symbols: Declarations/definitions of any global/static objects referenced by the above functions

explanation:
- UT_DefaultStubImplWithArgs (definition): The target function calls this directly. Any for-loop in its body (or its behaviour) must be inspected because the MISRA rule treats called functions as part of the for-loop body. Provide the full definition to check for for-loops, loop counters, and side-effecting objects.  
- UT_GetStubEntry (definition): Called by UT_DefaultStubImplWithArgs; if it contains for-loops or modifies/uses objects that are used as loop counters or flags in its callers, those must be examined.  
- UT_ClearStubEntry (definition): Same reason as UT_GetStubEntry — its body could contain for-loops or modify objects relevant to loop well-formedness in callers.  
- UT_Stub_FindRetvalConfig (definition): Same reason — needs to be inspected for any for-loops or modifications of objects used as loop counters/flags.  
- UtAssert_Message (definition): Called by UT_DefaultStubImplWithArgs; include its body because its behaviour is part of the called-function behaviour and could contain loops or side effects.  
- UtAssert_Abort (definition): Same as above — may contain control-flow or side effects relevant to loop semantics.  
- UtAssert_GetContext (definition): Same as above — include its definition for complete analysis.  
- Declarations/definitions of any global/static objects referenced by the above functions: The MISRA clauses refer to objects modified inside the for-loop body; to determine whether a loop counter/flag is also modified elsewhere, you must see the declarations and uses of globals that the functions read or write.  
- Type definitions/declarations for UT_EntryKey_t and int32: Needed to understand if any of these types are used as loop counters/flags (e.g. underlying signedness/width) or if typedefs hide other semantics.  
- va_list / va_start / va_end (stdarg.h) declarations: Include these declarations to fully resolve the target function's use of varargs; while not directly a loop concern, they complete the symbol table and may be needed if called functions inspect varargs or use them in loops.

Provide the listed function definitions and the declarations of any globals they reference; with those symbols the next analyzer can search for any for-statements and verify the three clauses and single loop-counter constraints across the target function and its callees.
